newsitem.title: GERMANY: U.S. soybean stocks seen down, Latam crops higher.
newsitem.headline: U.S. soybean stocks seen down, Latam crops higher.

text.p: U.S. soybean stocks are down sharply on a year ago, but Latin American new crop supplies will help ease global tightness between March and August, independent newsletter Oil World said on Tuesday.
The publication put U.S. March 1 soybean stocks at 29.8 million tonnes, down by 2.6 million from a year earlier.
Brazil's crop from the current harvest was estimated at 26.5 million tonnes compared with 23.5 million last year.
In Argentina, the crop should be 13.5-14.0 million tonnes, versus 12.4 million last year, given enough rains in key growing areas.
Strong demand had been seen for beans and meal from China, Mexico, the European Union and others.
Oil World said demand for oilseeds would develop so strongly that even larger Latin American crops would not help create enough supply for 1997/98.

To create a more even balance, U.S. spring plantings of 66-67 million acres were needed, which would be one or two million acres more than U.S. analysts were expecting, and soybean prices needed to rise versus corn to achieve this.
